ripe 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
  • Get started

ripe

The goal of ripe is to create a more flexible way to rerun {magrittr} pipes.

Installation

remotes::install_github('yonicd/ripe')

Goal

We want to write the following in a shorter and more flexible way


f <- function(){
  
  stats::runif(20)%>%
    sample(10)%>%
    utils::head(5)
}

replicate(n=3,f(),simplify = FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.78736989 0.06703113 0.89184340 0.01431260 0.91580381
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.08663225 0.07581781 0.39826775 0.99931286 0.50771596
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.5526908 0.8815062 0.1558228 0.3009755 0.2729172

This is better!

stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.2606433 0.4891663 0.1323022 0.2635266 0.5323940
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.8275172 0.7317866 0.4879555 0.1191955 0.4652014
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.9188807 0.9123656 0.8873663 0.8440759 0.8637520
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.3565037 0.5001946 0.4957345 0.7793354 0.4075865

Manipulate Chain Replicates

We can now manipulate the chain or move ripe around into different subsets of the chain, creating iterative replication workflows.


stats::runif(20)%>%
  #sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.83111380 0.08244948 0.37452057 0.31801164 0.05956422
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.6997109 0.5881944 0.4226823 0.8123013 0.4835087
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.4899323 0.6787718 0.5203132 0.8496389 0.5174136
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.34848163 0.70064280 0.06276376 0.25996788 0.47242639

Convert Chains to Lazy Functions

You can also quickly convert the chain to a lazyeval function

f <- stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  lazy()

f()
#> [1] 0.2408163 0.6800579 0.9117417 0.3898033 0.8181865
f()
#> [1] 0.03444434 0.95106606 0.08595653 0.59349949 0.57340944
